case_title: PATCHALA SEETHARAMAIAH vs COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX AND ANOTHER

accussed_details.name: PATCHALA SEETHARAMAIAH
allegation: Failure to pay tax within prescribed period under Voluntary Disclosure of Income Scheme, 1997

complaint_summary: Petitioner sought refund of Rs. 23,281 paid under the Voluntary Disclosure of Income Scheme, 1997, which was deemed void due to delayed payment.
investigation_summary: The petitioner filed a declaration under the scheme on December 27, 1997, disclosing income for 1991-92 and 1992-93. Tax payment was delayed by one day beyond the prescribed three-month period, rendering the declaration void under Section 67(2). Respondents refused refund citing Section 70 of the scheme.
judgment_summary: The court held that retention of tax paid under a void declaration is unconstitutional under Article 265 of the Constitution. Section 70 does not apply to void declarations. Petition allowed; respondents directed to refund the tax within two months unless adjusted against arrears.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition allowed; refund of tax ordered.
legal_arguments: Petitioner argued that Section 67(2) renders declarations void if tax is paid beyond the prescribed period, making retention of tax illegal.
Respondents argued that Section 70 prohibits refund of tax paid under the scheme under any circumstances.
key_issues: Whether tax paid under a void declaration can be retained by the Revenue.
Interpretation of Sections 67(2) and 70 of the Voluntary Disclosure of Income Scheme, 1997.

maxims.Article 265 of the Constitution of India: No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law.

legal_terms.Void Declaration: A declaration deemed never to have been made due to non-compliance with statutory requirements.

summary_vector_notes: Petitioner sought refund of tax paid under a void declaration due to delayed payment under the Voluntary Disclosure of Income Scheme, 1997. Court ruled retention of tax unconstitutional under Article 265 and directed refund within two months.
